reviews.review_text: This is a moving tale of life and death in the underbelly of Continental Europe during WW II.  It is also a touching love story.  Remarque is a wonderful writer.I read this in the original German which is very doable for someone with a good knowledge of school German.
Amazing that a novel written in German and translated to English could have such dense, meaningful, and perfectly chosen English wording that immerses you into the story.
This book made me buy a one way ticket to Lisbon! A great read, full of love, and history and human tragedy.
It has bearing on how we treat refugees today. This is again a serious problem in Europe and xenophobia on our part is not the right approach.

I read this book as part of a personal quest to read novels/memoirs by authors who have experienced the life of a refugee. It's a heartbreaking work of fiction with an unhappy ending. Despite being set in 1939, it feels familiar and contemporary, and is a sharp reminder of the fact that today's Europe has learnt few lessons from its own refugee experiences, a mere two generations ago.
One of my all time favorite book for many years!!
Beautiful love story, written with force and subtlety. The protagonists are drawn to each other through World War II and the novel rests on simple and eloquent prose.

summary:
History and fate collide as the Nazis rise to power in The Night in Lisbon, a classic tale of survival from the renowned author of All Quiet on the Western Front.
 
With the world slowly sliding into war, it is crucial that enemies of the Reich flee Europe at once. But so many routes are closed, and so much money is needed. Then one night in Lisbon, as a poor young refugee gazes hungrily at a boat bound for America, a stranger approaches him with two tickets and a story to tell.
 
It is a harrowing tale of bravery and butchery, daring and death, in which the price of love is beyond measure and the legacy of evil is infinite. As the refugee listens spellbound to the desperate teller, in a matter of hours the two form a unique and unshakable bond—one that will last all their lives.
 
“The world has a great writer in Erich Maria Remarque. He is a craftsman of unquestionably first rank, a man who can bend language to his will. Whether he writes of men or of inanimate nature, his touch is sensitive, firm, and sure.”—The New York Times Book Review
